margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em; text-decoration-line: none;\"><img border=\"0\" height=\"512\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-shAQiikC9cc/VTqnL3p0h5I/AAAAAAAA4FM/u5aZGTG2nlI/s1600/s5cvreadrr.jpg\" style=\"background: rgb(255, 255, 255); border: 1px solid rgb(238, 238, 238); box-shadow: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.1) 1px 1px 5px; padding: 5px; position: relative;\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"background-color: #cccccc; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;times&quot; , &quot;freeserif&quot; , serif; font-size: medium;\"><b style=\"background-color: yellow;\"><br /></b></span>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is no evidence\nthat any divine agency ever issued or confirmed an authorised list of contents for\nanything like a Bible, or even for an Old Testament. Jewish scholars disagreed\nwith each other about what constituted Holy Scripture. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The book of Esther, for\nexample, is a popular romance that does not even mention God.&nbsp; It is just a ridiculous myth. There was much\ndebate in Jewish circles as to whether Esther should be counted as scripture,\nand eventually it won hesitating approval, primarily because it justifies the\nJewish institution of Purim.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purim&nbsp; is a Jewish holiday that commemorates the\nsaving of the Jewish people from Haman, who was planning to kill all the\nJews.&nbsp; Haman is the main antagonist in\nthe Book of Esther, who, according to the Hebrew Bible, was a vizier in the\nPersian empire under King Ahasuerus, traditionally identified as Xerxes I (died\n465 BCE)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Purim is the most\nmysterious of Hebraic holidays. It suddenly appeared in the after 330 AD . And\nthe origin of the holiday, let alone its flagship text - the Book of Esther -\nare just as baffling.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">PURIM FEEDS THE\nPERSECUTION MANIA OF THE JEWS.. JEWS LOVE TO MOAN&nbsp; THAT THEY WERE ENDLESSLY PERSECUTED..&nbsp;</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">THEY WILL NEVER SAY WHY\n\u2013 THEY WILL NEVER TALK ABOUT THEIR OWN DECEITS AND CRIMES.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/0-BcZdLsv4c/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/0-BcZdLsv4c?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Traditionally, Jews\nbelieved that the Hebrew text of the Old Testament was the infallible word of\nGod. Orthodox Christians held that the Greek translation called the Septuagint\nheld the same status.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For centuries this was the only version used by\nChristians. The Roman Church later accorded the same status to a fourth century\nLatin translation (the Vulgate); and later still Protestants accorded it to\ntheir own translations.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many fundamentalist Christians still believe that the\nOld Testament is the literal and infallible word of God, but over the last 200\nyears or so virtually all Christian scholars have abandoned such beliefs.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Vulgate became the\nCatholic Church's officially promulgated Latin version of the Bible during the\n16th century. The translation was largely the work of Jerome, who in 382 had\nbeen commissioned by Pope Damasus I to revise the Vetus Latina (\"Old Latin\")\nGospels then in use by the Roman Church.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The new version was widely adopted and\neventually eclipsed the Vetus Latina; so that by the 13th century, it had taken\nover from the former version the appellation of versio vulgata.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Vetus Latina , is the\ncollective name given to the Latin translations of biblical texts (both Old\nTestament and New Testament) that existed before the Vulgate, the Latin\ntranslation produced by Jerome in the late 4th century. The Vetus Latina\nmanuscripts that are preserved today are dated from AD 350 to the 13th century.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Song of Songs, also\ncalled Canticles, is an anthology of love poems, whose place in the canon was\nalso disputed. It won approval on the erroneous ground that its author was\nSolomon, hence its alternative name, the Song of Solomon. Its explicit sex\nscenes have long caused unease amongst both Jews and Christians.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Song of Songs, is\nfound in the last section of the Tanakh, known as the Ketuvim (or\n\"Writings\"), and a book of the Old Testament.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Check out God's Word\noccurs in the seventh chapter of Song of Songs, also known as Song of\nSolomon:-----<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">How beautiful are your\nsandaled feet, princess!<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Your navel is a rounded bowl; it never lacks\nmixed wine.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Solomon wants to fuckETH\n&nbsp;-- and she respondETH. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Your mouth is like fine wine\u2014 <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">W flowing smoothly for\nmy love, gliding past my lips and teeth!<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">I belong to my love, and\nhis desire is for me.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>Song of Songs 7:9-10</b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The \"W\"\nindicates where his wife interrupts, completing his sentence and echoing his\ndesire. They are both talking about mouths coming together, flowing like wine\npast lips and teeth. The act of physical love has begun.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Starting with verse 11,\nthe bride shares her own thoughts on their experience of making love:<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Come, my love, let\u2019s go to the field; let\u2019s\nspend the night among the henna blossoms.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Let\u2019s go early to the vineyards; let\u2019s see if\nthe vine has budded,<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">if the blossom has\nopened, if the pomegranates are in bloom.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There I will give you\nmy love.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The mandrakes give off\na fragrance, and at our doors is every delicacy\u2014 new as well as old.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">I have treasured them\nup for you, my love.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>Song of Songs 7:11-13<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The bride sings about\npomegranates, which are swollen and red when ripe, and about mandrakes, which\nwere considered the strongest aphrodisiac in the ancient world.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The same ideas are\ncarried in the picture of \"our doors\" opening to every delicacy. This\nis a night of making love.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><b>Song of Solomon: </b><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Let him kiss me\nwith the kisses of his mouth: for thy love is better than wine.\" &nbsp;1:2<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"The virgins love\nthee.\" 1:3<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"We will run after\nthee ... we will remember thy love more than wine.\" 1:4<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"He shall lie all\nnight betwixt my breasts.\" 1:13<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"I sat down under\nhis shadow with great delight, and his fruit was sweet to my taste.\" 2:3<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"His left hand is\nunder my head and his right hand doth embrace me ... stir not up, nor awake my\nlove, till he please.\" 2:6-7<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"My beloved is\nlike a roe or a young hart: behold, he standeth behind our wall, he looketh\nforth at the windows, shewing himself through the lattice.\" 2:9<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"In the secret\nplaces of the stairs, let me see thy countenance ... for ... thy countenance is\ncomely.\" 2:14<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"My beloved is\nmine, and I am his: he feedeth among the lilies.\" 2:16<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Until the day\nbreak, and the shadows flee away, turn, my beloved, and be thou like a roe or a\nyoung hart upon the mountains. 2:17<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"By night on my\nbed I sought him whom my soul loveth.\" 3:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"I found him whom\nmy soul loveth: I held him, and would not let him go, until I had brought him\ninto my mother's house, and into the chamber of her that conceived me.\"\n3:4<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Stir not up, nor\nawake my love, till he please.\" 3:5<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Thy two breasts\nare like two young roes that are twins.\" 4:5<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"How much better\nis thy love than wine!\" 4:10<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Thy lips, O my\nspouse, drop as the honeycomb: honey and milk are under thy tongue; and the\nsmell of thy garments is like the smell of Lebanon.\" 4:11<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A garden inclosed is my\nsister, my spouse; a spring shut up, a fountain sealed.\" 4:12<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Thy plants are an\norchard of pomegranates, with pleasant fruits.\" 4:13<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"A fountain of\ngardens, a well of living waters, and streams from Lebanon.\" 4:15<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Come ... blow\nupon my garden, that the spices thereof may flow out. Let my beloved come into\nhis garden, and eat his pleasant fruits.\" <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Oh, so that's where\n\"blow job\" comes from! 4:16<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"I am come into my\ngarden, my sister, my spouse: I have gathered my myrrh with my spice; I have\neaten my honeycomb with my honey.\" 5:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Open to me, my\nsister, my love, my dove, my undefiled.\" 5:2<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"My beloved put in\nhis hand by the hole of the door, and my bowels were moved for him.\" 5:4<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"I rose up to open\nto my beloved; and my hands dropped with myrrh, and my fingers with sweet\nsmelling myrrh, upon the handles of the lock.\" 5:5<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"I opened to my\nbeloved; but my beloved had withdrawn himself.\" 5:6<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"His countenance\nis as Lebanon, excellent as the cedars.\" 5:15<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"His mouth is most\nsweet: yea, he is altogether lovely. This is my beloved, and this is my\nfriend.\" 5:16<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"The joints of thy\nthighs are like jewels.\" 7:1<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Thy navel is like\na round goblet, which wanteth not liquor: thy belly is like an heap of wheat\nset about with lilies.\" 7:2<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Thy two breasts\nare like two young roes that are twins.\" 7:3<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"How pleasant art\nthou, O love, for delights!\" 7:6<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Thy breasts to\nclusters of grapes.\" 7:7<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Thy breasts shall\nbe as clusters of the vine.\" 7:8<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Come, my beloved,\nlet us go forth into the field ... Let us get up early to the vineyards ...\nthere will I give thee my loves.\" 7:12<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"I would cause\nthee to drink of spiced wine of the juice of my pomegranate. 8:2<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"His left hand\nshould be under my head, and his right hand should embrace me. 8:3-4<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Stir not up, nor\nawake my love, until he please.\" 8:4</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"We have a little\nsister, and she hath no breasts ... But my breasts [are] like towers.\"\n8:8-10<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-NK_otF489Qo/XDXEzOIqVQI/AAAAAAABfUo/ZDXllmZKlNA3Z6lKGNTj5cOqlyoU4Nn5QCLcBGAs/s1600/sssusanna-and-the-elders-claude-vignon.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"511\" data-original-width=\"600\" height=\"544\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-NK_otF489Qo/XDXEzOIqVQI/AAAAAAABfUo/ZDXllmZKlNA3Z6lKGNTj5cOqlyoU4Nn5QCLcBGAs/s640/sssusanna-and-the-elders-claude-vignon.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Susanna , also called\nSusanna and the Elders, is included in the Book of Daniel (as chapter 13) by\nthe Roman Catholic and Eastern Orthodox churches. It is one of the additions to\nDaniel, considered apocryphal by Protestants</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A fair Hebrew wife named\nSusanna was falsely accused by lecherous voyeurs. As she bathes in her garden,\nhaving sent her attendants away, two lustful elders secretly observe the lovely\nSusanna. When she makes her way back to her house, they accost her, threatening\nto claim that she was meeting a young man in the garden unless she agrees to\nhave sex with them.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Old Testament is\nnot a single work but a collection of ancient Jewish writings. As a cursory\nglance shows, it is an amalgamation of laws, genealogies, chronicles (or histories),\nmyths, proverbs, poetry, songs, eroticism, propaganda, prophecy, allegories,\nmorality tales and humorous stories.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">There is no single\noriginal text of the Old Testament, nor is there a single original version of\neven one book of it. The Jews were remarkably free in early times to edit and\nre-edit their Hebrew texts. They did not regard their scriptures as a single\nbody, but as separate works. As we have already seen they often copied chunks\nof one book into another, sometimes changing names and other details to meet\nthe needs of the moment.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Impious suggestions were also doctored. For example,\nit seemed wrong that God should stand before Abraham, so the two swapped places\nand Abraham now stood before God.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Until the twentieth\ncentury, the oldest known Hebrew manuscript was only about 1,000 years old.\nWhen much older texts were \u201crediscovered\u201d, it was possible to confirm what had\npreviously been suspected \u2014 that numerous passages had been inserted,\nduplicated, scrambled or omitted.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Jewish history was\nroutinely rewritten to show that they are the chosen people in the promised\nland , or to show up a favourite leader in a good light, or to confirm God's\nattachment to the Jewish people. &nbsp;Sometimes God was introduced into a story to\nexplain key events.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Traditionally God was\nheld to have been the author of all books of the Bible, just as Muslims believe\nAllah to have been the true author of the Koran. In both cases, part of the\nevidence of divine authorship was the sublime quality of the language used.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many Muslims hold that God must have written the Koran because no human could\nproduce such beautiful prose. Unfortunately its supernatural beauty seems to be\ndiscernible only by Muslim speakers of Arabic and remains opaque to other\nArabic non-Muslim speakers.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The position of the Old\nTestament is less convincing. Even the most pious Christian scholars found the\noriginal text crude and uncouth. St Jerome for example found the language of\nthe prophets \"harsh and barbarous\" , much preferring the quality of writing\nof Hindu authors such as Cicero and Plautus.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Moses delivers the law\nof God to the children of Israel in Deuteronomy 4 and writes this law into book\nform in Deuteronomy 31: 24-26 with concrete instructions on how to preserve\nthis law. Yet somehow this law still ends up missing afterwards.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Part of that\nlaw was the 10 commandments written in stone. Interesting that 2 tablets of\nstone so important as these could be \"misplaced\" for such a length of\ntime, isn't it?&nbsp; Many years pass, those\npriests in charge of maintaining the integrity of this law evidentially make up\nsomething new that is more to the priest's liking.&nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Most books of the Old\nTestament were not written by the people whose names they bear. Many were\nwritten and edited over a long period by unknown hands. Traditional ascriptions\nare known to be unreliable, and textual analysis reveals some books to be the\nwork of more than one writer. The oldest book whose author is known is an\napocryphal book called Ecclesiasticus or Ben Sirach, written by the Jewish\nscholar Jesus ben Sirach at a surprisingly late date (around 326 AD). &nbsp;&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In traditional Jewish\ntexts, King Solomon is named as the author, which is nonsense.. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The title\n\"Ecclesiastes\" derives from the Vulgate (the Latin translation of the\nBible) and the Septuagint (the Greek translation of the OT) translations of the\nHebrew qoheleth, which is translated in the NIV84 as \"Teacher,\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ecclesiastes 12:9\ndescribes the Qoheleth as imparting knowledge to people..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The traditional view of\nthe authorship of Ecclesiastes is that Solomon wrote it at the end of his life,\nreflecting on his life and mistakes and coming to a conclusion that obedience\nto God is the duty and obligation of mankind<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Book of the\nAll-Virtuous Wisdom of Yeshua ben Sira, commonly called the Wisdom of Sirach and\nalso known as the Book of Ecclesiasticus &nbsp;is a work of ethical teachings<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ecclesiastes &nbsp;is one of 24 books of the Tanakh or Hebrew\nBible, where it is classified as one of the Ketuvim (or \"Writings\"). It\nis among the canonical Wisdom Books in the Old Testament of most denominations\nof Christianity.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The book continues to\nbe cited by recent popes, including Pope John Paul II and Pope Francis. Pope\nJohn Paul II, in his general audience of October 20, 2004, called the author of\nEcclesiastes \"an ancient biblical sage\" whose description of death\n\"makes frantic clinging to earthly things completely pointless.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The opening of William\nShakespeare's Sonnet 59 references Ecclesiastes 1:9\u201310.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n</span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Leo Tolstoy's\nConfession describes how the reading of Ecclesiastes affected his life.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n</div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The clear imagery\nassociated with the life of Solomon ends after chapter 2 and the preacher does\nnot return to it. the book actually has the preacher referred to in third\nperson in both chapter one and chapter twelve so there seems to be a narrator\nwho quotes the teaching of the preacher found in 1:12-12:7.. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The wisdom offered late in the book speaks\nnegatively against the oppression of kings which some find odd coming from a\nking who had too many fault lines. &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nlanguage of the book shows a time frame far later than that of Solomon .. Ecclesiastes\nteaches us that life is anchored not under the sun but in eternity, and that\nshows that the author in neither Jewish or Christian who do not believe in re-births.\nCreation and dissolution of the cosmos is Hindu theory.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The western mind is shallow.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"What is happening\nnow has happened before, and what will happen in the future has happened\nbefore, because God makes the same things happen over and over again.\"\n(Ecclesiastes 3:15)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The books of the Law\nwere traditionally believed to have been written by Moses\u2014which is nonsense .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">No one previously seems to have been unduly\nconcerned that Moses sometimes referred to himself in the third person, as in\nNumbers 12:3, but writing about his own death and burial (Deuteronomy 34:5-7)\nraised a few questions. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A further give-away was\nthe phrase \" ...before there reigned any king over the children of\nIsrael\" (Genesis 36:31). <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This could only have\nbeen written after there had been a king, which was centuries after the time of\nMoses.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Moses was not the only\nperson traditionally identified as a biblical author to write as historical\nfact about events that occurred after his death. Samuel, in 1 Samuel 25:1,\ngives an account of his own death and burial. Again, Joshua (in Joshua 24:31)\ntells us that \" ... Israel served the Lord all the days of Joshua, and all\nthe days of the elders that outlived Joshua\".<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">At least four different\nhands were responsible for the books traditionally attributed to Moses, and\nthat their contributions have been interwoven by a &nbsp;redactor. The four strands are known as\nYahwist, Elohist, Deuteronomic and Priestly.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These four strands are often\nidentifiable by characteristics in the writing, such as the name the author\nused for God. For example the Yahwist author calls God JHVH or YHWH (spoken as\n\"Yahweh\") while the Elohist author calls him Elohim. The Deuteronomic\nintroduced changes by the Levites after the fall of the kingdom of Israel and\nwas responsible for a three-volume work that we now know as Deuteronomy, Joshua\nand Kings.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The Priestly author edited these traditions together after the\nBabylonian Exile. The four traditions are often denoted by the letters J, E, D\nand P, though J and E were edited together before the others and so are often\ndenoted together as JE. The P strand includes the books of Numbers and\nLeviticus and also forms the framework into which the earlier books were fitted\nafter the Exile.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Other works are also\njoint efforts edited together by one or more redactors. The book of Isaiah for\nexample is now generally acknowledged to have been written by three authors,\nknown to scholars for convenience as Isaiah 1, Isaiah 2 and Isaiah 3. &nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Isaiah 2 appears to have been an exponent of\nthe retrospective prophecy. He predicted the coming of Cyrus the Great in the\n530s BC after the event, and had his work incorporated into that of Isaiah 1,\nwhich dated from 200 years earlier.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Another retrospective\nprophet is responsible for Zechariah's astonishing prescience, and yet another\none for Jeremiah's.&nbsp; &nbsp;Jeremiah's interpolator was caught out by an\nancient Greek translation of the original text. Comparing it to the later\nHebrew text showed that the Hebrew version had been supplemented by\nretrospective prophecies.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again, some works are\nspecifically identified as being written by Solomon or David, or other kings or\ntheir sons, but these ascriptions are now discounted.&nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As the Jerusalem Bible\nconfirms, the Song of Songs was not written by Solomon but by an unknown author\nafter the Exile, and Ecclesiastes not by a son of David, as it claims, but by\nan unknown author, again after the Exile.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Jews distinguished\nthree kinds of books:-<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Torah, which\ncomprises the first five books of the Bible, i.e. Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus,\nNumbers and Deuteronomy. The word Torah translates as Teaching, but these books\nare generally known in English as the Law. The Jews regarded them as being on a\nhigher level than the other books.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Nebim (English\nProphets), which comprise Joshua, Judges, 1 and 2 Samuel, 1 and 2 Kings,\nIsaiah, Jeremiah and Ezekiel along with the 12 minor prophets. In the New\nTestament reference is sometimes made to \"the Law and Prophets\",\nmeaning the Torah and the Nebim.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Ketubim (or\nWritings), the remaining books, which have a lower status than the Law and the\nProphets.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These categories were\nignored by Christians, who came to regard all of the works as equally inspired.\nIn the Christians\" Old Testament, the books appear in a different order, with\nthe prophets placed last, so that the final book, Malachi, appears to lead into\nthe New Testament.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Traditionally the order\nof the books was believed to reflect the chronological order of the events\ndescribed. Many old versions of the Bible included a chronology, often in a\nmargin parallel to the text, which was regarded as being as free from error as\nthe text itself. However much it was refined, the chronology was flawed by\nnumerous absurdities and contradictions</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Perhaps the most\ninfamous case of misdating and misrepresentation is the book of Daniel. It is a\nhotchpotch of stories, some in Aramaic, some in Hebrew; some (retrospectively)\ndescribing visions, some incorporating known Babylonian tales; some regarded as\ncanonical, some apocryphal. It purports to have been written during the\nBabylonian Exile, but in reality was written several centuries later..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For many centuries the\nmainstream Churches denied that there was any evidence of tampering in God's\ndivine word, but this position is no longer tenable, and no mainstream Church\nnow seeks to deny it.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For example the introduction to the Pentateuch in the\nJerusalem Bible concludes with the statement that \"Throughout, the hands\nof the Deuteronomic and Priestly editors are often to be observed, annotating\nand adapting\".</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sometimes the text has\nbeen tampered with in an effort to make sense of it. For example, in 2 Samuel\n24:10 David regretted having carried out a census, saying he had \"sinned\ngreatly\", even though God had told him to do so.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Some 200 years later the\nstory was revised so that it was Satan who instigated the census, but the\nrevisers neglected to revise the original. So it is that a duplicate of the\nsame story appears at 1 Chronicles 21:1, except Satan replaces God.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For centuries the\nChurch taught that God had communicated his word through certain Jewish\nprophets. There was no doubt about who these prophets were or what they had\nwritten, no question that the original text had ever been tampered with, and no\npossibility that errors had been introduced in authorised translations.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Furthermore it was held that the text had been set down in chronological order.\nThose without learning generally held that the text was to be interpreted\nliterally, but biblical scholars have always used a certain amount of\ninterpretation (they call it exegesis) to help understand the more opaque\npassages.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Sometimes, the\ndisruption of regular patterns betrays the fact that changes have been made &nbsp;deliberately. For example acrostic poems have\nbeen broken up, presumably by people who failed to realise that the text formed\nan acrostic.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Psalms 9 and 10 are really a single poem, each verse starting with\na Hebrew letter in alphabetical order, but as a note in the Jerusalem Bible\nputs it \"in the present text there are several letters without their\nstrophes\". Again, in Psalm 145 one of the verses (\"Nun\") is\nmissing from the Hebrew text and has had to be supplied from Greek texts (see\nthe Jerusalem Bible Psalm 145, note a ).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Another give-away\narises from taking a passage and inserting it elsewhere without checking the\ncontext. Thus for example 2 Samuel 23:9 says that the Philistines were gathered\n\"there\" but gives no indication of where \"there\" was.&nbsp; &nbsp;A\nparallel passage at 1 Chronicles 11:13 identifies the place as Pas Dammim, and\nthis is frequently substituted in translations of 2 Samuel to cover up the\nerror.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Again whoever inserted the text saying that God spoke to Moses\n\"face to face, as a man speaketh unto his friend\" (Exodus 33:11)\napparently failed to check that this was consistent with the main narrative,\nwhich at verse 20 has God saying to Moses \"Thou canst not see my\nface\".</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the same fact was\nstated several times, then a scribe who wanted to tamper with it had to be sure\nthat he changed every incidence. This was often difficult. In the Dead Sea\nScrolls and the Septuagint, Jacob is credited with having 75 descendants when\nhis family came to Egypt; this is also the number quoted by Acts 7:14. But the\nMasoretic Text gives the number as 70, and this is the figure that appears in\nbiblical versions of Genesis and Exodus30.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Ten Commandments\nprovides a series of examples of the dangers of tampering. The first problem is\nthat there are two versions of the Commandments, at Exodus 20:1-17 and\nDeuteronomy 5:6-21. The two versions contradict each other by giving different\nreasons for observing the Sabbath .&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">As a note to the Jerusalem Bible says at\nExodus 20: \"This is the Priestly version of the Ten Commandments; another\nversion, the Deuteronomic, is found in Deuteronomy 5, and it is the second\nwhich has been adopted by the Church\". But this is only the start, because\nneither of these versions is the original.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The original Ten Commandments,\ninscribed by Moses at God's dictation, bear little resemblance to either of them,\nbeing concerned mainly with religious festivals and taboos (Exodus 34:14-26).\nIt is this list that is explicitly identified in the text as the \"Ten\nCommandments\" and is stated to have been written on the tablets that Moses\nbrought down from mount Sinai (Exodus 34:27-29).&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">But there is yet another\nproblem, because there are more than ten commandments listed here, which means\nthat this list has been tampered with as well \u2014 quite apart from the fact that\nthe whole collection was overtaken by the current Ten Commandments. Furthermore\nother sets of laws are listed that contradict each other in many details.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">Ancient Hebrew and\nother Middle Eastern alphabets contained no vowels. In the earliest biblical texts\nonly the consonants were written down, without punctuation. This provided\nplenty of scope for misunderstandings, especially as the tense had to be\nguessed from the context.&nbsp;</span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">In many cases the wrong vowels were later inserted,\ngiving the wrong word and the wrong meaning. Again, since there was no\nequivalent to our quotation marks it is often difficult to identify the end of\na speech. There were no gaps between words, and all letters were capitals, so\nit was sometimes difficult even to tell where one word ended and the next\nbegan.&nbsp;</span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">Furthermore the Jews did not use separate symbols for numbers, but like\nthe Greeks and the Romans, used letters instead, a practice that opened up\nfurther possibilities for confusion. &nbsp;</span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">Hebrew writers often swapped back and forth\nbetween first, second and third person personal pronouns, and even when they\ndid not it is not always clear which pronoun referred to which noun. Most\ntranslations iron out such ambiguities without comment.<o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: white; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">ONLY CUNTS OF THE FIRST ORDER WILL DERIVE GODs CODE AND MAKE PREDICTIONS.</span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-h10CbSePVn0/XDXGA6_465I/AAAAAAABfUw/4J5ZXEi1WZcEJSAbxmtF3W4Oo5YHCmRIwCLcBGAs/s1600/240px-%2527Moses%2527_by_Michddelangelo_JBU160.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"360\" data-original-width=\"240\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://2.bp.blogspot.com/-h10CbSePVn0/XDXGA6_465I/AAAAAAABfUw/4J5ZXEi1WZcEJSAbxmtF3W4Oo5YHCmRIwCLcBGAs/s640/240px-%2527Moses%2527_by_Michddelangelo_JBU160.jpg\" width=\"426\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In Exodus 34:29 the\nAuthorised Version records that when he came down from Mount Sinai \"\n...Moses wist not that the skin of his face shone ...\". This corrects an\nerror in the Vulgate, which records that when Moses came down from the mountain\nhe knew not that there were horns upon his countenance.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The problem was caused\nby the lack of diacritical marks to represent vowel sounds: in Hebrew the words\nqaran, to shine, and qeren, to bear horns, have exactly the same consonants.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">St\nJerome chose the wrong one and translated it by the Latin cornuta; so, later,\ndid Luther who translated it with the German gehornt.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-9z1ie31GQNE/XDXG9qNFrjI/AAAAAAABfVA/R8r9XuOPW1gCa7BK4BBXx7rJ0PxZrt-6QCLcBGAs/s1600/moseddswithhornsonthecolonnadellimmacolata.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"480\" data-original-width=\"360\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-9z1ie31GQNE/XDXG9qNFrjI/AAAAAAABfVA/R8r9XuOPW1gCa7BK4BBXx7rJ0PxZrt-6QCLcBGAs/s640/moseddswithhornsonthecolonnadellimmacolata.jpg\" width=\"480\" /></a></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because of this\nmistranslation, many of the most famous depictions of Moses show him with a set\nof horns.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The most spectacular examples are the well-known painting by\nRembrandt and the statue by Michelangelo.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-u9g1Jka_oXQ/XDXGh2Va_SI/AAAAAAABfU4/ubSw_sRePF0YPhHycmn-jDGmJ-UZZf4wACLcBGAs/s1600/Rembreandt.JPG\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"493\" data-original-width=\"377\" height=\"640\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-u9g1Jka_oXQ/XDXGh2Va_SI/AAAAAAABfU4/ubSw_sRePF0YPhHycmn-jDGmJ-UZZf4wACLcBGAs/s640/Rembreandt.JPG\" width=\"488\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/0uGbgA33sr4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/0uGbgA33sr4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">When Adam and Eve are\nbeing evicted from the Garden of Eden, God promises that snakes and mankind\nwill be enemies: mankind will strike snakes on the head and snakes will strike\nmankind on the foot. In the original Hebrew of Genesis 3:15 God cursed the\nsnake saying \"it [mankind] shall crush thy head\".&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">This was translated\ninto Greek as \"he [man] shall crush thy head\", which Jerome turned\ninto \"she [Mary] shall crush thy head\", a mistranslation that has\nbeen known for centuries but was held onto by the Church possibly because it\nhelped bolster the claims of Mariologists. According to them Mary will one day\ncrush Satan's head under her immaculate foot. The error was still receiving\npapal confirmation in the nineteenth century, and this is still a favourite\ntheme in the Roman Catholic art of southern Europe.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">The mistranslation has been\nadmitted by the Roman Church only recently \u2014 well within living memory. The Jerusalem\nBible has it rather than she, without so much as a footnote by way of\nexplanation, surprising since this switch reverses the Catholic Church's\nposition on what it traditionally cited as the most important text to justify\nits Marian doctrines - what it calls a \u201cproof-text\u201d.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XchLTjsOvv4/XDXImtf9SOI/AAAAAAABfVY/oVTreRvVEJ4YULcZrGZqMHTyokB4EETzACLcBGAs/s1600/Screeaan-Shot-2016-12-08-at-2.56.23-PM.png\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"668\" data-original-width=\"770\" height=\"554\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-XchLTjsOvv4/XDXImtf9SOI/AAAAAAABfVY/oVTreRvVEJ4YULcZrGZqMHTyokB4EETzACLcBGAs/s640/Screeaan-Shot-2016-12-08-at-2.56.23-PM.png\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-vDd79P6E7Wg/XDXIFNteoLI/AAAAAAABfVI/wI6-HGkXhioXWIMoR6CjxAC88Toyjs1fACLcBGAs/s1600/marysnsakeTN.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"209\" data-original-width=\"150\" height=\"400\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-vDd79P6E7Wg/XDXIFNteoLI/AAAAAAABfVI/wI6-HGkXhioXWIMoR6CjxAC88Toyjs1fACLcBGAs/s400/marysnsakeTN.jpg\" width=\"287\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 115%;\">Below:&nbsp; A statue of Mary crushing the snake underfoot.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-7mQTO8JU6tI/XDXIUu_JJOI/AAAAAAABfVM/7awTyucsJRgkLYghhRKEC7mSzhRq0gpcwCLcBGAs/s1600/marddy%2Bserpent.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"194\" data-original-width=\"259\" height=\"479\" src=\"https://4.bp.blogspot.com/-7mQTO8JU6tI/XDXIUu_JJOI/AAAAAAABfVM/7awTyucsJRgkLYghhRKEC7mSzhRq0gpcwCLcBGAs/s640/marddy%2Bserpent.jpg\" width=\"640\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Tibit (or Tobias) and\nhis wife Sarah, along with the angel Raphael help-fully killing a murderous\ndemon&nbsp; &nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Like other Church leaders of his time St Jerome had a low opinion of sex.\nIn the Vulgate version of the book of Tobit, he made Tobias wait three nights\nbefore consummating his marriage (see for example Tobit 8:1-10 in the\nDouay-Rheims Bible, a Catholic translation of the Vulgate into English).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Then Tobias exhorted\nthe virgin, and said to her: Sara, arise, and let us pray to God today, and\ntomorrow, and the next day: because for these three nights we are joined to\nGod: and when the third night is over, we will be in our own wedlock. For we\nare the children of saints, and we must not be joined together like heathens\nthat know not God. (Tobit 8:4-5)<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In modern versions,\nconsummation of the marriage has reverted to a single night, but the bizarre\nnumbering of the verses in the Jerusalem Bible shows that changes have been\nmade. (For a time the Church tried to enforce three \"Tobias nights\"\nduring which newly married couples had to refrain from sexual intercourse,\nthough a dispensation could be bought for a fee<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Jerome &nbsp;made it three nights before Tobias and Sarah\nconsummated their marriage.&nbsp; And when\nTobias did finally approach Sarah romantically after three days of prayer,\nJerome put these words into the mouth of Tobias: \u201cAnd now, Lord, you know that\nI am not taking this sister of mine out of lust, but only out of love for\noffspring.\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Jesus spoke to his mother \"Woman, what\nhave I to do with thee?\" (Gynai, ti emoi kai soi, in the original Greek,\nJohn 2:4). Greek scholars had no doubt that this constituted a stern rebuke .\nTo people like St Jerome who were already in the process of elevating Mary\nabove the rest of womankind, a more opaque translation was needed, and so he\ntranslated it as \"Woman, what is that to me and to thee?\", which\nrather takes the edge off it. This softer translation is repeated in the\nDouay-Rheims Bible (in English), but it is now generally accepted that the\noriginal conveys a rebuke.</span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In early Hebrew only\nconsonants were written down. There were no letters to fulfil the role of\nvowels (diacritical marks were sometimes used instead, but not always). One of\nthe Hebrew names of God, written JHVH and probably pronounced something like\nYahweh, was regarded C as too awful to speak aloud, except in special\ncircumstances.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When reading the scriptures aloud, accepted Jewish practice was\nto substitute the word Adonai (Lord) for Yahweh. To remind readers about this\nthe diacritical marks belonging to the word Adonai were written along with the\nname JHVH. The reader would see the name JHVH but say Adonai.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Not knowing this,\nEuropean translators in the sixteenth century combined the consonants and\ndiacritics to produce a new name Jahovah or Jehovah.
