, &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Since the Hebrew\nalphabet doesn't include vowels, it should be much harder to find matches in\nthe English texts, because an additional character match is required for each\nvowel.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">THERE GOES THE JEW\nCONTENTION ( DOWN THE KOSHER SHITHOLE ) THAT THEY ARE CHOSEN PEOPLE WITH SPECIAL\nLANGUAGE <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-cl1pyuYuL9w/XCNYOIuME3I/AAAAAAABfJ0/FHETqE4qSUgp8G7CJHgj5xhZ_MorlZ6dwCLcBGAs/s1600/doSwnload.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"181\" data-original-width=\"279\" height=\"259\" src=\"https://1.bp.blogspot.com/-cl1pyuYuL9w/XCNYOIuME3I/AAAAAAABfJ0/FHETqE4qSUgp8G7CJHgj5xhZ_MorlZ6dwCLcBGAs/s400/doSwnload.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The concept of using\nstatistics to prove that 'God authored the Bible' is bullshit.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">YacovRambsel, includes\na chapter on \"The Laws of Probability\" in his book Yeshua, The Name\nof Jesus Revealed in the Old Testament, which is nonsense<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The problem with\nstatistics is that they have an unusual ability to say whatever you want them\nto say. Perhaps even unintentionally.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">These types of statistics\nare meaningless,&nbsp; because they measure\nthe probability of finding a specific phrase, rather than&nbsp; any meaningful phrase.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Statistics can be\nextremely subtle, and those fooled best are those who desperately want to see\nsomething in the shadows without considering the true light.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The names Mohammed, Krishna,\netc. have been found in accidental ELS all through these Biblical books\nhundreds of times. &nbsp;<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Mohammed was found\n2,328 times TEE HEEE . &nbsp;So Jew and\nMuslims are now BHAI BHAI, right?</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">What I see in all this\nis a revival of divination like tarot or the Ouija board that is authenticating\nitself through high technology that can in no way be of God. God communicates\nto man by his word . You may as well go look for pictures in the clouds to\nreceive information then mathematize words and letters to tell you something\nplainly written.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">READ AND UNDERSTAND MY\nPOSTS ON SPHOTA AND BHARTRHARI\u2014 THEY DON\u2019T HAVE THE CEREBRAL WHEREWITHAL<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">NO WESTERN MIND IS DEEP\nENOUGH TO GRASP BHARTRHARI.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/10/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_27.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/10/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_27.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/10/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_28.html\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/10/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and_28.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/11/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and.html\">https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/11/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: lime;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><a href=\"https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/11/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">https://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2018/11/sanatana-dharma-hinduism-exhumed-and.html</a><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<a href=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-H89GV2LPaQQ/XCNX9u6YOrI/AAAAAAABfJs/6OMjklchYtwF7bNtVgqF5W6X1xJUiWdZACLcBGAs/s1600/ddownload.jpg\" imageanchor=\"1\" style=\"margin-left: 1em; margin-right: 1em;\"><img border=\"0\" data-original-height=\"194\" data-original-width=\"259\" height=\"299\" src=\"https://3.bp.blogspot.com/-H89GV2LPaQQ/XCNX9u6YOrI/AAAAAAABfJs/6OMjklchYtwF7bNtVgqF5W6X1xJUiWdZACLcBGAs/s400/ddownload.jpg\" width=\"400\" /></a></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u201cHidden messages\u201d can\nbe found anywhere, provided the seeker is willing and able to harvest the\nimmense field of possibilities. But do they mean anything?&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Drosnin baby&nbsp;\narranges the 304,805 Hebrew letters of the Bible into a large array.\nSpaces and punctuation marks are omitted, and words are run together one after\nanother. A computer looks for matches to selected names or words by stepping to\nevery nth letter in the array. One can go forward or backward; and for each\nvalue of \u201cstep distance,\u201d n, there are n different starting letters. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Drosnin baby work with\nthe original Hebrew characters, which are said to have been given by God to\nMoses one character at a time, with no spaces or punctuation, just as they\nappear in \u201cthe code.\u201d The code is considered to exist only in the Hebrew Bible\nand not in translations or any other books. The<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When Drosnin finds a\nname or word match for a given step value n, he then rearranges the letters\ninto a huge matrix (which he calls a \u201ccrossword puzzle\u201d). The matrix is n\nletters wide, and inside this puzzle, the letters for the \u201chidden message\u201d line\nup together vertically. (Sometimes, a slightly different procedure is used to\nmake the hidden word run diagonally, every other row, and so forth.) The\nanalyst or the computer can then look for more keyword-related \u201chits\u201d around\nthe given hidden word. Secondary matches can be picked off vertically,\nhorizontally, or diagonally.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Jews and Christians\ncry, \u201cHow could such amazing coincidences be the product of random chance?\u201d The\nreal question should be, \u201cHow could such coincidences not be the inevitable\nproduct of a huge sequence of trials on a large, essentially random database?\u201d<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ironically, the Bible\nCodes themselves attempt to make use of \u201cscience\u201d by uncovering patterns in the\ntext that are discernible only by computational algorithms. Perhaps this is why\nthe con endures: It\u2019s just scientific-seeming enough to appeal to that band of\nJews appreciative of scientific discourse but, understandably, not well versed\nenough in statistics or mathematics to approach these claims critically. The Bible\nCodes are like Intelligent Design: religion garbed in science that, while\nobviously flawed to actual scientists, seems credible enough to laypeople.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">First we must ask the\nquestion: do we today have a version of the Hebrew text that is\nletter-for-letter the same as the text as originally written?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By its very nature the\nELS Code demands the acceptance of an essential presupposition, namely that the\nHebrew text we have today is letter-for-letter precisely the same as the text\noriginally penned by the various authors of the Old Testament.&nbsp;&nbsp; That is, in order for the Code to work, not\nonly must our present Hebrew text preserve the same number of characters as\ncontained in the original, but the letters also must be in the same order as\nfirst written.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The adoption of matres\nlectionis into the Hebrew text of the Old Testament by early Israelite scribes\nis only one of many problems with the popular ELS Code and represents only one\nof many such changes in Hebrew spelling habits incorporated by scribes into the\nOld Testament text. This is a KEY reasons why the ELS Code is invalid.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Orthographic changes to\nthe text of the Hebrew Old Testament did occur and thousands of textual\nvariants do exist, the Jews acnt deny this . Yet the thousands of orthographic\nchanges that affect the number and order of characters make any\n\"Code\" based on exact sequences of letters completely void. The\nMasoretes deliberately rearranged the letter sequences of the Hebrew text to\nproduce the Code.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Masoretes are Jewish\nscholars of the 10th centuries AD who contributed to the establishment of a\nrecognized text of the Hebrew Bible, and to the compilation of the Masorah.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By long tradition, a\nritual Sefer Torah (Torah scroll) could contain only the Hebrew consonantal\ntext \u2013 nothing added, nothing taken away. The Masoretic codices however,\nprovide extensive additional material, called masorah, to show correct\npronunciation and cantillation..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Cantillation is the\nritual chanting of readings from the Hebrew Bible in synagogue services.&nbsp; The Masoretes were not working with&nbsp; the original Hebrew manuscripts of the Bible.\nCorruptions had already crept into&nbsp; the\nversions they copied. That the Code was not original to the Old Testament&nbsp; text is clear to anyone familiar with the\nhistory of the transmission of the Hebrew text.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The original books of\nthe Hebrew Bible, written by the original authors, are called autographs. These\nautographs were written on scrolls made of animal skins or papyrus (a type of\npaper made from reed plants). Because these writing materials deteriorate over\ntime, it is unlikely that we will ever uncover an original autograph from the\nHebrew Bible. In order to preserve the text the text is copied over and over\nagain.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Aleppo Codex, the\noldest Hebrew Bible that has survived to modern times, was created by scribes\ncalled Masoretes in Tiberias, Israel around 930 AD. As such, the Aleppo Codex\nis considered to be the most authoritative copy of the Hebrew Bible. The Aleppo\nCodex is not complete, however, as almost 200 pages went missing between 1947\nand 1957.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">While the Aleppo Codex\nis the oldest Hebrew Bible, the Leningrad Codex is the oldest complete Hebrew\nBible.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A brief summary of the\ncodes claims is that the Hebrew text of the Bible (especially of the Torah, the\nfirst five books) contain intentional coincidences of words or phrases that\nappear as letters with equal spacing. . Every single&nbsp; alleged scientific evidence for the codes is\nbogus<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Many dimwit believers\nare using their computers \"for a form of divination\"&nbsp; like Timothy baby..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Take the&nbsp;&nbsp; entire Hebrew Bible eliminate all spaces and\npunctuation between the words so that there is only one continuous strand of\nletters throughout the Torah.&nbsp;&nbsp; The\nconmen&nbsp; claim that they are restoring the\nBible to its original form Moses received it in. Since they had to decide on\nthe word breaks. TEE HEEEE.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">You take this long line\nof 304,805 letters that make up the Torah and arrange them in an infinite\nnumber of computer configurations. For example, we could take the entire Torah\nand configure it into a long \"scroll\" of 10 lines only--which would\nmake each line 30,480.5 letters long. On a computer, we can make our scroll\nwith as many lines as we want--100 lines would mean there would be 3048 letters\non each line (except, perhaps, the last). 285 lines would make each line 1069\nletters long, etc.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Now you search for a\npredetermined set of words These words-- --were found in proximity by\nactivating the computer to hunt for such ELS words--starting with sequences\nof&nbsp;&nbsp; skips of 1, 2, 3, 4, up to 10, then\n20-50 letters&nbsp; etc. Code words can be\nfound with number skips into the thousands.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">When faith uses\nOBJECTIVE science to justify itself, it undermines itself as well. Surely\nreligious consciousness does not lie on the same axis as scientific proof. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">We should not turn to\nscience for values \u2014and we should not turn to religion for facts.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Bible Codes seek to\nerase the very essence of spirituality converting it from SUBJECTIVE TO\nOBJECTIVE<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It became a recruiting\ntool for ultra-orthodox Jewish yeshivas. And it amused, then frustrated,\nmathematicians worldwide. What made the codes especially eerie was that, while\nscientists were almost universally skeptical of them, nobody could figure out\nwhat was wrong with them<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Just as the Bible Codes\nmyth relativizes the nonrelative, so it absolutizes the nonabsolute. And that\nmeans, in turn, that the Jews really are the chosen people in the\nunreconstructed sense: We alone possess Divine revelation, and the Torah is\nabsolutely it.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Well, it\u2019s a good thing\nthe Bible Codes are nonsense, because that reactionary theology is the same cancer\nhas brought us Zionist fundamentalism and crusades . What the Bible Codes\nhawkers are teaching is not just pseudoscience, but also fanaticism.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Simple people became\nOrthodox ZIONIST Jews because of the codes.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If Torah / Bible is\ndivine and the others are so clearly not, there\u2019s very little space for religious\npluralism or tolerance. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">ELS\u2019s are not so\ncomplex as to require a supernatural deity or an extraterrestrial alien to\ncreate them even a halfwit can do it.. Some of the Hebrew letters involved are\namong the most frequently found in the Torah.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">I AM THE BEST ?<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/khqiC4HHccQ/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/khqiC4HHccQ?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Every text contains\nmany such \"codes,\" so the question was whether the observation of\ncodes with apparent meaning in Genesis was a deliberate message from the\nalmighty or mere coincidence.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Statistically such\n\"codes\" or patterns will occur by chance in any text of similar\nlength to the Old Testament, particularly one that includes no vowels as in the\nHebrew text .In biblical Hebrew vowels were not written, only consonants.\nVowels were supplied when someone read the text.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In many cases which vowels are supplied affects\nnot only pronunciation but also the meaning of a word. For example, the common\nHebrew noun for \"word\" (dabar) is written with the consonants d-b-r,\nthe two vowels (-a-a-) being supplied by the reader.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Yet the same three\nconsonants supplied instead with the vowels -e-e- (deber) form a word meaning\n\"pestilence.\" This and other characteristics of the Hebrew language\nmake it fairly easy to find or force specific meanings into a given string of\nconsonants<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Because there are\nhundreds of billions of ELS in the Torah, virtually every conceivable word or\nphrase will and does appear hundreds of thousands of times as an ELS.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The ELS experiment is\nextraordinarily sensitive to very small changes in the spellings of\nappellations<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Hebrew language is\nwritten without vowels and one can combine letters to create random words more\neasily than in western languages. For all this to be true one must prove that\nthe ' ELS was deliberately inserted in the text and is not a coincidence.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The\nclaim of kosher conmen is this can be accomplished through statistical\nprobabilities that the ELS is a deliberate code. We always have difficulty\nunderstanding a text where we don\u2019t have any syntax or punctuation.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In the plain Hebrew\ntext of the Torah, without punctuation I could easily read 10 commandments as\ntelling me to steal and murder. There\u2019s a verse that describes Moses being\ncommanded to bring kosher vinegar. I could easily read it as a commandment to\nuse pigshit <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Kosher \"data\ntuning\" for wiggle room alone could account for the effect. <o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">JEW Drosnin baby had\nused the flexibility of Hebrew orthography to his advantage, freely mixing\nclassic (no vowels, Y and W strictly consonant) and modern (Y and W used to\nindicate i and u vowels) modes, as well as variances in spelling of K and T, to\nreach the desired meaning.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">In a Newsweek\ninterview, Drosnin baby made the claim that if anyone can find assassination\npredictions in other works besides the bible, he would essentially, shut up\nabout the Bible code. An Aussie Brendan McKay responded by finding no less than\n9 similar \"predictions\" in the text of Moby Dick.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/Y1JPjqDc6Qs/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/Y1JPjqDc6Qs?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">A WEE\n\"wiggle\" room, was capable of generating a desired result --&nbsp; a hoax, an intentionally and carefully\ndesigned \"magic trick\"- &nbsp;mindless\ncherry picking at its best.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">My most telling\nevidence against the 'codes' is that I cannot find them.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Word clusters\nidentified by code promoters are an \u201cuncontrolled phenomenon\u201d and expected in\ntexts of \u201csimilar length.\u201d All claims of incredible probabilities for such\nclusters are bogus, since they are computed contrary to standard rules of\nprobability and statistics..<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Their only \u201csuccessful\u201d\nresults were obtained by deliberately rigging the experiment in such a way that\nthe layman wouldn't recognize the mathematical flaws.\"<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The Bible Code is based\non the work of Eliyahu Rips, an Israeli mathematican and computer expert who,\nalong with two other authors (Doron Witztum and Yoav Rosenberg), in 1994\npublished an article in the prestigious academic journal Statistical Science.<o:p></o:p></span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/LaLRHJgU1B4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/LaLRHJgU1B4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/u2xyS6KW3Ac/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/u2xyS6KW3Ac?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both; text-align: center;\">\n<iframe allowfullscreen=\"\" class=\"YOUTUBE-iframe-video\" data-thumbnail-src=\"https://i.ytimg.com/vi/_ZQYynZcbH4/0.jpg\" frameborder=\"0\" height=\"266\" src=\"https://www.youtube.com/embed/_ZQYynZcbH4?feature=player_embedded\" width=\"320\"></iframe></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Rips\u2019 analysis was on\nthe Torah, the Five Books of Moses consisting of Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus,\nNumbers, and Deuteronomy. Rips eliminated the spaces between all the words in\nthe Torah, converting it into one continuous strand of 304,805 letters. With\nthis strand he applied the ELS process where you start with the first letter of\nGenesis and then enter a \u201cskip code\u201d program by taking every nth letter, where\nn equals whatever number you wish-every 7th letter, 17th letter, 3,007th\nletter, or whatever it takes to find meaningful patterns. If there are none\nthere you start with the second letter, or the third, and so on.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The vowels are added to\nthe letters after the skip search. If it were English, RBN could be Rabin, or\nit could be Ruben, or Robin, or Rubin, or Rabon, or, or, or\u2026 And you do this\nsearch not only from right to left (as Hebrew is read), but from left to right,\nup to down, down to up, and diagonally in any direction. You can either have a\nname or word in mind ahead of time then search to find it, or you can look at\nthe sequence of letters to find a meaningful name or word<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">It was noticed several\ndecades ago by Rabbi Weissmandel that the word Torah&nbsp; occurs spelled out as T, O, R, H&nbsp;&nbsp; (in their Hebrew equivalents)&nbsp; in the Book of Genesis by starting from the\nfirst T.&nbsp; The 50th letter after that T is\nan O. The 50th letter after the O is an R.&nbsp;\nAnd the 50th letter after the R is H.&nbsp;\nIn this example, the \"skip length\" is 50 letters. It turns out\nthat TORH is spelled out more than 56,000 times in the Book of Genesis (with\nvarious skip lengths).&nbsp; Genesis itself is\nslightly more than 78,000 letters long.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;The theory is that hidden words and sentences\ncan be found \"embedded\" in the Hebrew text of the Old Testament&nbsp; by counting Hebrew letters at equally spaced\nintervals. That is, a person can locate certain meaningful words or phrases, such\nas \"hammer\" and \"anvil,\" if he examines the letters at\nsequences that were equally spaced in the Hebrew text.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Thus, \"if he found\nthe first letter of a significant word such as Torah, and then, by skipping\nforward seven letters he found the second letter of the word Torah, he would\ncontinue to skip forward the same number of letters to see whether or not the\ncomplete word Torah was spelled out in the text at equally spaced intervals<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The number 50 has\nseveral important meanings in Judaism. The 50th is the Jubilee year, there are\n49 days of Omer which are counted from the second day of Passover until the\nShavuot which is the 50th day, and there are also 50 gates of wisdom in Torah.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\"Torah\"\nsystem with intervals of 50 (corresponding to the 50 gates of wisdom) he was\nlooking again for intervals of 50.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">If the cylinder were 49\n(or 50) letters around, the 49-letter interval skip pattern letters would line\nup in a series of vertical lines (see note 2). One could read them \u201cacross the\nwindings,\u201d just like \u201ccoded\u201d messages written on a ribbon wrapped on a pole of\na particular diameter can be read by rewinding the ribbon onto another cipher cylinder\nof the same diameter.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Genesis 1:1\u20134. Biblia\nHebraica from Kittel's edition (BHK) 1909. Four letters, 50 letters apart,\nstarting from the first taw on the first verse, form the word \u05ea\u05d5\u05e8\u05d4 (Torah).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Exodus 1:1\u20136. Biblia\nHebraica from Kittel's edition (BHK) 1909. Four letters, 50 letters apart,\nstarting from the first taw on the first verse, form the word \u05ea\u05d5\u05e8\u05d4 (Torah).<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">By taking every 50th\nletter of the Book of Genesis starting with the first taw, the Hebrew word\n\"torah\" is spelled out. The same happens in the Book of Exodus.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Let\u2019s go to the\nbiblical book of Genesis, or, more specifically, to the Hebrew text of it,\nknown as B\u2019reishit, and look at the first four verses.&nbsp; Let\u2019s start with the first word in the first\nverse, b\u2019reishit. The last letter of b\u2019reishit is the Hebrew letter tav. Now\nlet\u2019s look for the letter which is fifty letters away from that tav.</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">&nbsp;Let\u2019s\nrepeat that process two more times, each time skipping forty-nine letters and\nseeking the next letter that is fifty letters away from the one we just\nfound.&nbsp; If you count carefully, when you\nreach the third letter in the second word of the fifth verse in B\u2019reishit, the\nfour Hebrew letters you find in this sequence are tav, vav, resh and hey.\nTogether, in that order, they spell Torah, the first five books of the Tanakh,\nthe Hebrew Bible.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Congratulations! You\nhave just uncovered a hidden Bible code, one formed by an equidistant letter\nsequence, or ELS. Skeptics can repeat the exercise, and get the same result, as\nthe beginning of the next book in the Hebrew Bible, the book of Exodus, known in\nHebrew as Sh\u2019mot.&nbsp; Find the first tav in\nthe first verse of Sh\u2019mot (it\u2019s at the end of the second word) and the next\nthree letters each 50 letters apart. Again, if you are careful, you should find\nthe sequence tav, vav, resh and hey, or Torah.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Too simple? A mere\ncoincidence, you say? Wait, there\u2019s more.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This time, start at\nExodus 11:9. Find the first letter in the name Moshe (Moses), a mem. Now apply\nthe 50 letter ELS process and you should find the letters shin, nun and hey. If\nso, you have uncovered the word Mishneh.&nbsp;\nNext, go back to the mem in Moshe. Skip 613 letters to reach the tav in\nthe third word in Exodus 12:11 and begin the 50 letter ELS process once more.&nbsp;</span><br />\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Ending at the second hey in the first word of Ex. 12:13, you should, once\nagain, find the tav-vav-resh-hey sequence, which spells Torah.&nbsp; And there you have it: the great work of the\nincomparable sage Moses Maimonides, his legal code, the Mishneh Torah,&nbsp; is not only referenced in the Torah itself,\nthe two title words are linked by the exact number of commandments in the\nTorah, 613.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">For any remaining\ndoubters, the first letters in the last four words in Exodus 11:9 are\nresh-mem-bet-mem, which spell Rambam, the acronym for Maimonides\u2019 full Hebrew\nname, Rabbi Moshe ben Maimon. So, in addition to ELS\u2019s, we also have related\nwords in proximity to each other. This is known as a word cluster.&nbsp; And there is even more in Ex. 11:9-12:13 (see\nhere (at 1/27)), but you get the point.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Abbi Akiva died 135 AD\nwas a Kerala sage\u2014a teacher of astronomy.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">He is referred to in\nthe Talmud as Rosh la-Hakhamim \"Chief of the Sages\". He was executed\nby the Romans in the aftermath of the Bar Kokhba revolt. he was subjected to\ncombing, a Roman torture in which the victim's skin was flayed with iron combs.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span>\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span><br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\">\n<a href=\"http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/11/bar-kokhba-in-fight-to-finish-over.html\" style=\"background-color: lime;\">http://ajitvadakayil.blogspot.com/2010/11/bar-kokhba-in-fight-to-finish-over.html</a><o:p></o:p></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">What was Rabbi Akiva\nlike? - A worker who goes out with his basket. He finds wheat - he puts it in,\nbarley - he puts it in, spelt - he puts it in, beans - he puts it in, lentils -\nhe puts it in. When he arrives home he sorts out the wheat by itself, barley by\nitself, spelt by itself, beans by themselves, lentils by themselves. So did Rabbi\nAkiva; he arranged the Torah rings by rings.</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 12pt;\">&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">\u2014\u2009Avot deRabbi Natan\nch. 18; see also Gittin, 67a<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Here is lore-- 'When\nMoses ascended into heaven, he saw God occupied in making little crowns for the\nletters of the Torah. Upon his inquiry as to what these might be for, he\nreceived the answer, \"There will come a man, named Akiva ben Yosef, who\nwill deduce Halakot from every little curve and crown of the letters of the\nLaw.\" Moses' request to be allowed to see this man was granted; but he\nbecame much dismayed as he listened to Akiva's teaching; for he could not\nunderstand it.' This story gives a picture of Akiva's activity as the father of\nTalmudic Judaism.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Akiba ben Yosef is\nreferred to in the Talmud as Rosh la-Hakhamim \"Chief of the Sages\".\nHe was executed by the Romans in the aftermath of the Bar Kokhba revolt.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">WE ASK THESE JEWISH\nCODE BREAKERS..&nbsp; <o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: red;\">SEMITES</span><span style=\"color: blue;\"> FROM KERALA\n(&nbsp; DISGRACED </span><span style=\"color: red;\">LEFT HANDED</span><span style=\"color: blue;\"> YOUNGER BROTHERS\nOF NAMBOODIRIS ) CREATED RIGHT TO LEFT HEBREW..&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">THESE WERE HOMOSEXUALS\nWHO WERE SECLUDED ON MINICOY ISLAND AND ORDERED &nbsp;TO BE CIRCUMCISED BY THE CALICUT KING TO AVOID\nSHIT GETTING UNDER THE FORESKIN AND RESULTING VENEREAL DISEASE/ ORAL/ STOMACH &nbsp;DISEASE. .&nbsp;\n<o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">WHY DO THESE JEWISH\nCODE BREAKERS ANALYSE FROM LEFT TO RIGHT ?&nbsp;\nWHERE IS THE INTELLIGENCE ?&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">CODES\nWERE WRITTEN IN HEBREW FOR ENGLISH SPEAKING PEOPLE?</span></b></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\">BRAAAAAYYYYYYYYYYY !<o:p></o:p></span></b></span></div>\n</div>\n<span style=\"background-color: cyan;\"><b><span style=\"color: blue;\"><br /></span></b></span>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b>In a dynamic changing\nworld of multiple languages and cultures we can all understand the SUBJECTIVE spiritual\nmessage ( Bible is OBJECTIVE \u2013 Bhagwad Gita is SUBJECTIVE )<o:p></o:p></b></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: yellow; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><b><br /></b></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">All vowels and spaces\nare removed from the&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">letters of the Torah,\nand then, on command via a computer program, those letters&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; The horizontal row is&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">just composed of the\nrunning Torah text. </span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; How impressive is this fuckin\u2019\nprediction?<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">The possibility of an\nattempt on Rabin's life was well known to Mossad .<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Drosnin's memo to\nIsrael's chief scientist at the Israeli Ministry of Defense stated: \"I\nthink Rabin is in real danger, but that the danger can be averted\" (p.\n187). font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">That the ELS for\n\"Yitzhak Rabin\" crossed the words (under the Drosnin's dubious\ntranslation) \"assassin who will assassinate\" no more predicts that\nRabin will be assassinated than that Rabin himself will assassinate.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Moreover,\nthere is no indication which Yitzhak Rabin is referred to (this is a very very\ncommon name &nbsp;in Israel like Singh or\nSharma in India ).&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">As with the Delphic Oracle, the interpretation of the Bible\nCode depends on what the interpreter wants it to. The success of Drosnin's\nprediction is only in the eyes of the beholder.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\">&nbsp;Lest skeptics dismiss this claim&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">out of hand, readers\nwere told, \u201cThe&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">code was broken by an\nIsraeli mathematician, who presented the proof in a&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">major science journal,\nand it has been&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">confirmed by famous\nmathematicians&nbsp;</span><span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\">around the world\u201d</span></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">The Bible, Drosnin argued,\nwas more than an ancient story. It was a computer program! (See, e.g., Id. at\n25, 45, 98, 179.) &nbsp;&nbsp;And it needed to be\nstudied and decoded by the chosen people in the promised land.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Needless to say, The\nBible Code became an international best seller.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">And it begat Bible Code II: The Countdown (Viking 2002), which claimed\n(at 5-9) that the air assault on the Twin Towers in New York in 2001 was\nanticipated in the Torah, and predicted (at 4-5, 106-08) an atomic holocaust in\n2006, a nuclear world war, precipitated by terrorism in the Middle East.&nbsp;</span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\"><br /></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">A third\nbook, The Bible Code III (Worldmedia 2010) followed as well, and promoted the\nnotion that Osama bin Laden possessed a nuclear bomb.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">The primary lure of the\nBible Code books was, of course, the implication that God encrypted messages in\nthe text of the ancient Torah, messages that Drosnin, building on the work of\nWRR, was able to tease out of the text. Conversely, the messages might be taken\nas scientific proof that God exists and the Hebrews are special.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">Drosnin asserts,\nrepeatedly, that he is a non-believer. (See, e.g., The Bible Code, at 61, 79,\n181.) But he also argues that \u201cno human\u201d could have anticipated the events\nwhich he claims are referenced in the text. (Id. at 50-51) Rather\n\u201cnon-human&nbsp; intelligence\u201d designed the\ncode, proving that \u201cwe are not alone.\u201d&nbsp;\n(Id. at 90, 97, 179.)<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">As to the source of the\nnon-human intelligence, Drosnin quotes Rips as confirming that his (Drosnin\u2019s)\nfindings are \u201cnon-random,\u201d and that they were placed in the text by a \u201chigher\nintelligence,\u201d by which Rips, an Orthodox Jew, means God, a deity who acted\nintentionally.<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3; font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , serif; font-size: 14pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">BRAAAAAYYYYYYYYYYYY !<o:p></o:p></span></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<br /></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 14.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: #f3f3f3;\"><span style=\"color: purple;\">AARRGGHHH &nbsp;PPTHHEEOOYYYYYYYYYYY !!</span></span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 200%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 18.0pt; line-height: 200%;\"><span style=\"background-color: white;\"><b><span style=\"color: red;\">Deliberate alterations\nof translations have been done to make ELS work/. These conmen should be fined\nand incarcerated for cultural terrorism</span></b></span><o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">Jew Michael Dov\nWeissmandl&nbsp; searching for encoded words\nand phrases, and wrote out the entire 304,805 letter&nbsp; sequence of the Torah on 10 letter-by-10 letter\ngrids.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">The&nbsp; impression a reader is given upon initial\nexposure to the \"code\" is that one need only&nbsp; group the Hebrew letters in a page of the\nTorah and start looking for encrypted&nbsp; sequences,\nmuch like working on a word-finder puzzle.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">This is not the case.&nbsp;</span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\"><br /></span></div>\n<div class=\"MsoNormal\" style=\"line-height: 150%;\">\n<span style=\"font-family: &quot;times new roman&quot; , &quot;serif&quot;; font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 150%;\">With the&nbsp; advent of computers, proponents of Bible\ncodes can (and do) put any ELS figure into the&nbsp;\ncomputer and look for results. In other words, the procedure is more\nlike taking that same word-finder puzzle and then rearranging it over and over\nagain until you find something meaningful.<o:p></o:p></span></div>\n<br />\n<div class=\"separator\" style=\"clear: both;
